question: [File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: AEAD] [Nonce reuse] Can malformed messages cause the AES-256-GCM nonce to be reused for different plaintexts, completely breaking authentication and allowing message forgery? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: AEAD] [Tag truncation] Can fuzz data cause the authentication tag to be truncated or shortened, reducing security from 128 bits to fewer bits and enabling practical forgery attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: HKDF] [Weak key derivation] Does the Noise protocol implementation properly use HKDF for key derivation, or can an attacker manipulate inputs to cause weak or related session keys to be derived? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: Hash] [Collision attacks] Could pre-image or collision attacks on the hash function used in Noise allow an attacker to forge handshake transcripts and bypass authentication? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: Padding] [Padding oracle] Can timing differences in decryption error handling leak information about plaintext padding, allowing an attacker to decrypt messages through a padding oracle attack? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: Side channels] [Timing attacks] Do constant-time comparisons protect against timing attacks in key comparison and authentication tag verification, or can an attacker use timing measurements to extract key material? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: Side channels] [Cache attacks] Can an attacker use cache timing side channels during cryptographic operations in the handshake to recover ephemeral or long-term private keys? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Cryptography: Randomness] [Weak RNG] Does TEST_SEED in KEYPAIRS generation use a cryptographically secure RNG, or could weak randomness allow an attacker to predict future keys if this code path is used in production? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Noise IK] [Pattern violation] Can an attacker send messages that violate the Noise IK handshake pattern (e <- s, e, es, ss), causing the protocol implementation to enter an undefined state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Noise IK] [Ephemeral key reuse] Can malformed handshake messages cause ephemeral keys to be reused across multiple handshakes, breaking forward secrecy and allowing session key recovery? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Noise IK] [Static key confusion] Can an attacker exploit confusion between static and ephemeral keys in the handshake to cause incorrect key material to be used for session key derivation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Noise IK] [Handshake hash] Can manipulation of the handshake hash (transcript) allow an attacker to cause different peers to derive different session keys while believing the handshake succeeded? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Noise IK] [Payload encryption] Does the fuzzer test payload encryption in handshake messages (lines 99 with fake_timestamp), or can an attacker exploit vulnerabilities in payload handling to leak keys or bypass authentication? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Identity verification] [Public key binding] Is the static public key properly bound to the handshake transcript to prevent key substitution attacks where an attacker replaces the remote peer's public key mid-handshake? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Forward secrecy] [Key deletion] Are ephemeral private keys properly zeroized after the handshake completes, or could they leak from memory allowing an attacker to compromise past sessions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Protocol: Session resumption] [Ticket forgery] If session resumption is implemented, can an attacker forge resumption tickets to bypass full handshake authentication and establish unauthorized sessions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Network: Peer validation] [Peer ID spoofing] Can an attacker manipulate the handshake to cause incorrect peer_id to be extracted at line 106, allowing them to impersonate a validator in subsequent consensus messages? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Network: Connection hijacking] [Session takeover] After handshake completes, can an attacker inject messages into the established NoiseStream to hijack the connection and send forged consensus or transaction messages? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Network: Validator impersonation] [Key substitution] Can fuzzing detect if an attacker can substitute a validator's public key during handshake to impersonate that validator and participate in consensus with Byzantine behavior? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Network: Message integrity] [MAC forgery] Can an attacker forge message authentication codes on encrypted post-handshake messages to inject malicious consensus proposals or votes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Network: DoS resistance] [Handshake flooding] Can an attacker flood validators with handshake attempts containing malformed data that consumes excessive resources, degrading validator performance below consensus liveness threshold? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Validator: Crash attacks] [Panic exploitation] Can Byzantine peers craft handshake or encrypted messages that trigger panics in honest validators, gradually reducing the number of live validators below 2/3 and halting consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Validator: State corruption] [Session state] Can malformed messages corrupt NoiseSession internal state causing subsequent legitimate messages to be rejected, partitioning the validator from the network? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Validator: Resource leaks] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker establish many half-open handshakes that never complete, causing memory exhaustion and validator crash due to resource leaks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/network/framework/src/noise/fuzzing.rs] [Consensus: Network partition] [Split-brain] Can cryptographic failures in the Noise handshake cause validators to form separate network partitions, breaking AptosBFT safety assumptions and allowing double-spending? (Critical)
